data.title: Latin Grammys 2022: Jorge Drexler Wins Big, Bad Bunny Follows, Rosalía Nabs Album of the Year
data.meta_description: Bad Bunny and Jorge Drexler lead list of winners so far at the 2022 Latin Grammy Awards
data.text:
It was a battle of icons and superstars, with Bad Bunny and veteran singer/songwriter Jorge Drexler duking it out for the most wins at the 2022 Latin Grammys, held Thursday (Nov. 17).

But the battle was ultimately won not by the most-streamed and highest-grossing artist on the planet, but by Drexler, the beloved Uruguayan singer/songwriter known for his complex, often cerebral fare.

While an absent Bunny won five awards, including best urban album for Un Verano Sin Ti, Drexler took home a total of six awards (seven if we include the Latin Grammy for best arrangement for Fernando Velazquez for Drexler’s “El plan maestro”), including record and song of the year for “Tocarte” alongside C. Tangana, a song he says he wrote in six hours.

Drexler also won best pop song (“La guerrilla de la concordia”), best alternative song (“El día que estrenaste el mundo”), best singer/songwriter album (for Tinta y Tiempo), and best Portuguese language song (alongside Marisa Monte in “Vento Sardo”).

The wins, in the face of formidable competition (Rosalia, and Karol G were also up for the song and record awards), were surprising to some, including Drexler himself, who asked “Are you sure?” when he got up to receive the song of the year award.

Drexler proceeded to gracefully acknowledge the importance of urban music today, saying: “I want to dedicate this award to everyone who does urban music in Spanish because you’ve taken our music to places it was never in before […] We have a beautiful language and Latin culture goes from Borges to Bad Bunny,” he added backstage.

Beyond Bunny, whose wins included best urban fusion performance and best urban song for “Titi me preguntó,” no other urban act won multiple awards. The exception was Rosalía (who is not a core urban act), a self-avowed fan of tropical and urban Latin music and reggaetón, who took home best alternative music album for her genre-bending, highly layered Motomami, best recording package for the set and the all-important album of the year award.

A visibly surprised Rosalía shed tears in her acceptance speech.

“Many, many, many thanks. Motomami is the album that I’ve most had to fight for, that’s been hardest to do, but I kept going,” she said. “Thanks for always supporting my music, because my music is always changing,” she added, before launching into a long list of thank-yous that included her famous boyfriend, Rauw Alejandro.

“Thank you to the love of my life. Baby, I love you,” she said pointing toward Rauw in the first row.

Although some may see the list of Latin Grammy winners as a rebuke of urban music’s domination in the Latin music world, it’s actually more of an acknowledgement that there is much more to “Latin” music than charts would suggest. And one of the foundations is the long-standing singer/songwriter tradition of songs with deep content and social context which Drexler is part of.

“A song is a genre as respectable and serious as a film. I always made songs with deep personal conviction. My only drive was to create beauty that was really connected to what I really felt.”

Along those lines, perhaps not surprisingly, the producer of the year award went to Julio Reyes-Copello, a classically-trained pianist known for big, complex pop arrangements. And Argentine singer/songwriter Fito Páez won all three awards he was up for, including best rock song, best pop/rock album and best pop/rock song for “Babel,” a track with Carlos Vives on Vives’ album Cumbiana II.

“If I’m getting this award, certainly it’s because of Fito, but also, because of my love for Argentine rock,” said Vives, whose Cumbiana II also won the Latin Grammy for best contemporary tropical album. “I was never a fan of the Beatles. I didn’t even learn English at home. But I always listened to Argentine rock.”

Sebastian Yatra, who truly broke out this year with his album Dharma, also took home two awards, including pop vocal album and best pop song for his infectious bop “Tacones Rojos,” which he sang alongside John Legend in one of the best performances of the evening.

Beyond the big wins, perhaps the highlight of the evening was the best new artist tie between 95-year-old Angela Alvarez and 25-year-old Silvana Estrada.

Both do acoustic-leaning music that’s bound to the traditions of their respective home countries: Cuba for Alvarez, Mexico for Estrada. Other than that, they couldn’t be more different. Alvarez, who has long written songs, was encouraged by her grandson two years ago to actually record the music she only sang at home. She was “discovered” by Andy García and put on the map, and now, on a global stage.

On her end, Estrada, who has been lauded as one of the bright new voices of Latin music, was a big favorite to win the award with her personal songs and extraordinary vocals.

Backstage, Alvarez said she’d love to record a second album, “But only God and I will tell. Music is the language of the soul,” she added, and when asked to sing what was on her mind, she sang a cappella a song she wrote years ago, dedicated to her native Cuba.

The Latin Grammy Awards aired live on the Univision network from the Michelob Ultra Arena at the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino in Las Vegas.

The full list of winners is below, with winners in bold.
